import cv2
import numpy as np

# Load the image
img = cv2.imread('board.jpg')

# Convert the image from BGR to HSV color space
hsv = cv2.cvtColor(img, cv2.COLOR\_BGR2HSV)

# Calculate the histogram of each channel
h, s, v = cv2.split(hsv)
hist\_h = cv2.calcHist([hsv],[0],None,[180],[0,180])
hist\_s = cv2.calcHist([hsv],[1],None,[256],[0,256])
hist\_v = cv2.calcHist([hsv],[2],None,[256],[0,256])

# Find the peak value of each histogram
peak\_h = np.argmax(hist\_h)
peak\_s = np.argmax(hist\_s)
peak\_v = np.argmax(hist\_v)

# Identify the channel with the highest peak value as the dominant color channel
if peak\_h > peak\_s and peak\_h > peak\_v:
 print("The background color of the sign board is red.")
elif peak\_s > peak\_h and peak\_s > peak\_v:
 print("The background color of the sign board is green.")
else:
 print("The background color of the sign board is blue.")

ZM, +1.45% disclosed in a Thursday filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has fired Greg Tomb, who served as the company’s president. Tomb only joined Zoom back in June, at which time he was announced as overseeing “go-to-market strategy, revenue efforts, and office of the Global CIO.” SVB MoffettNathanson analyst Sterling Auty noted after Thursday’s SEC filing that Tomb’s firing comes after Zoom’s latest outlook implied “a bigger deceleration than the Street had modeled” for enterprise growth, “and now we have a change being made in the executive that was brought in for sales leadership.” Auty is looking to understand “if Zoom will be hiring / appointing a new person to fill the role,” he said in a note to clients, while adding that normally “sales leadership transitions take three quarters to play out.” Chief Executive Eric Yuan announced layoffs in early February impacting 15% of staff, while adding that executives would be seeing pay cuts. Zoom shares were off 0.9% in after-hours trading Thursday. The stock has lost 42% over the past 12 months, as the S&P 500 SPX, +0.76% has declined 9%.

ZOOM Video Communications abruptly terminated the employment of president Greg Tomb, a former Google executive who had only started at the videoconferencing company in June.

Tomb will receive severance benefits in accordance with arrangements that are payable upon a “termination without cause”, the company said in a regulatory filing. The move is effective on Friday (Mar 3).

A spokesperson for San Jose, California-based Zoom said the company isn’t looking to find a replacement at this time and declined to comment further.
The executive had taken a high-profile role at Zoom during his short tenure, appearing on earnings calls and overseeing the company’s sales operation. He reported directly to chief executive officer Eric Yuan, who started Zoom in 2011 and had to rapidly build up the business during a pandemic-fuelled boom. More recently, the company has been cutting jobs to deal with softening demand.

Tomb’s employment included a US$45 million stock grant that would vest over four years, in addition to a US$400,000 base salary with an 8 per cent bonus target, according to a June filing.

In an interview with Bloomberg during the January World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Tomb spoke optimistically about Zoom’s growth potential while acknowledging that the company faced more competition. A few weeks later Zoom announced it would cut 15 per cent of its workforce.
